docs.lead_paragraph: Wearing socks to bed just may help people fall asleep. That is because the body appears to prepare for sleep by widening the blood vessels in the hands and feet to help radiate body heat away, according to a study in Switzerland. This phenomenon is closely related to the release of hormones like melatonin that regulate sleepiness and wakefulness.

headline.main: Curling Up With a Nice Pair of Socks

docs.abstract: Study finds that wearing socks to bed may help people fall asleep (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: Products promising significant weight loss are nothing new. But the television infomercials for two new diet supplements, Exercise in a Bottle and Fat Trapper, are remarkable even in that genre. Advertisements claim that, taken in concert, the two supplements, sold by Enforma Natural Products of Los Angeles, take the place of exercise. In the half-hour infomercial, being shown widely, the former baseball player Steve Garvey and a nutritionist, Kendall Carson, tell viewers they can consume fattening foods and still lose weight simply by taking a few pills every day. (The regimen costs $35 a month.)

headline.main: Not So Fast, Critics Say of Diet-Pill Claim

docs.abstract: Weight-loss claims made in infomercials for Exercise in a Bottle and Fat Trapper are challenged by consumer advocates; two district attorneys in California file lawsuits accusing Enforma Natural Products, the marketer, of false advertising (M)
docs.snippet: Products promising significant weight loss are nothing new. But the television infomercials for two new diet supplements, Exercise in a Bottle and Fat Trapper, are remarkable even in that genre.    Advertisements claim that, taken in concert, the two...

docs.lead_paragraph: Coffee lovers, take heed. For the sake of your health, you might consider switching at least some of those daily cups of java for tea. Not herbal tea but ''real'' tea -- green tea, black tea, Chinese tea, fruit-flavored tea, with or without caffeine, lemon, milk or sugar. As long as the leaves come from the plant Camellia sinensis, tea will contain potent antioxidant chemicals that have been linked to protection against major diseases like cancer and heart disease. Even the caffeine in tea may be somewhat beneficial, emerging evidence suggests.

headline.main: Tea: The Latest Health Food (but Hold the Clotted Cream)

docs.abstract: Jane E Brody Personal Health column on health-promoting properties of 'real' tea--green, black and oolong; notes such teas contain antioxidant chemicals that have been linked to protection against major diseases like cancer and heart disease (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Vaccinations may one day be simply a matter of a quick shower -- or maybe just a shampoo. Scientists at Stanford University have found that a simple solution of DNA and water applied to the skin of mice can induce an immune response against the hepatitis B virus. The response is comparable to that from traditional injection into the muscle, the research shows.

headline.main: Vaccines May Soon Have Punch But No Ouch

docs.abstract: Scientists at Stanford University find that simple solution of DNA and water applied to skin of mice can induce an immune response against hepatitis B virus; research shows that response is comparable to that from traditional injection into the muscle; in the study, DNA, which sets off body's immune response against hepatitis B, is applied directly to mouse skin with no preliminary scraping or chemical hair removal; drawings (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: ''Immanent Justice'' may sound like the title of a Jackie Chan movie, but it is the name developmental psychologists use for a widely held, if erroneous, assumption: that illness can be a punishment for bad behavior. A new study reported at the annual meeting of the American Psychological Association last month indicates that under some circumstances otherwise reasonable adults may adopt this karmic explanation.

headline.main: So You Think You Deserved to Get Sick?

docs.abstract: Study presented at American Psychological Assn meeting indicates that some people think that illness is punishment for bad behavior (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: Everyone gets the late-night munchies now and then, whether for rocky road ice cream or a Dagwood sandwich of salami, pickles and deli Swiss on rye. For some, however, nighttime kitchen raids are frequent, uncontrollable and distressing.
docs.abstract: Researchers study behavior of obese Americans who cannot control their late-night raids on refrigerator; cartoon (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: Before Lisa Tiger got the awful news late in the afternoon of July 5, 1992, neither she nor any of her friends or relatives had heard of a Creek-Seminole Indian's getting a diagnosis of H.I.V. Though the AIDS epidemic was already a decade old, the disease was hardly ever discussed among American Indians. Ms. Tiger, then 27, set about to change that. That year, she told her own story about contracting the AIDS virus to 300 tribal leaders attending the annual National Congress of American Indians, who listened in stunned silence, then embraced her, and flooded her with invitations to speak at their reservations. ''I was booked solid for the next three years all over the country,'' Ms. Tiger said.

headline.main: AIDS Outbreak Feared for U.S. Tribes

docs.abstract: Health experts fear that AIDS is about to explode among 500 Indian tribes in United States; note that AIDS cases grew on Navajo reservation by about 25 percent in 1998, to current 101 cases; say tribal leaders are not paying attention to problem; Lisa Tiger, 27-year-old Creek-Seminole who contracted HIV, told her story to about 300 tribal leaders attending annual National Congress of American Indians in 1992, stunning listeners and spurring them to ask her to speak at their reservations; however, interest in AIDS among nation's 1.9 million Indians has since withered; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Only 100 confirmed cases of measles were reported in the United States in 1998, the fewest since health officials began tracking it in 1912. That is down from 138 cases in 1997 and 27,786 cases as recently as 1990, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention said last week. Officials say vaccination programs appear to have wiped out measles as an indigenous disease in the United States. ''We think that all the transmission is related to importation of measles virus from other countries,'' said Dr. Mark Papania, acting chief of measles elimination activity in the centers' national immunization program.

docs.lead_paragraph: No one is talking about a cure, or even any improvement in the very near future, but researchers are reporting some promising progress in the field of lupus, a serious autoimmune disease affecting about 1.5 million people in the United States. Scientists at the University of Texas say they have identified four genes that can halt the now incurable, potentially fatal disease. They published their findings in the current issue of Immunity.
docs.abstract: Researchers at University of Texas report some promising progress in field of lupus, identifying four genes that can halt the now incurable, potentially fatal disease (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: Her brother, an uncle, two aunts, two first cousins and a nephew: Louise Robinson quickly reels off a list of relatives with diabetes. Her parents may have had it, too, she guesses, since both died in their 40's from heart attacks, a common complication of diabetes. A cousin died from the disease in June after suffering its most dreaded complications, including blindness, kidney failure, heart attacks and infections in her feet that would have led to amputations had she lived. The cousin was in her 50's, like Ms. Robinson, and the two had been close.

headline.main: New Fronts In the War On Diabetes In Adults

docs.abstract: Diabetes Prevention Program, research program being conducted at 27 medical centers around United States, seeks to prevent Type 2 diabetes in people who are at high risk for disease through diet and exercise or with the drug metformin; researchers are also urging development of a drug to prevent insulin resistance, a genetic trait that may develop years before diabetes develops; Type 2, or 'adult onset,' diabetes is progressive, debilitating disease that has been gaining ground at alarming rate in recent years--partly, researchers say, because of Americans' growing tendency to inactivity and weight gain; has been diagnosed in more than 9 million Americans, and 5.4 million are estimated to have it without knowing it; photo; graph (M)
